summary: This document contains internal email correspondence from May 2008 among federal prosecutors and FBI personnel regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. The emails express frustration over delays in prosecution, concerns about statute of limitations, and arguments against allowing Epstein's counsel to further stall the case. They reference a plea deal, multiple victims, and investigative challenges.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein

events.title: Internal debate over Epstein prosecution delays
events.description: Federal prosecutors and FBI personnel exchange emails arguing against further delays in the Epstein case, citing statute of limitations concerns, victim welfare, and grand jury expiration.

events.title: Epstein's counsel requests to present further arguments
events.description: The Deputy Attorney General (DAG) is inclined to allow Epstein's counsel to present additional arguments, prompting prosecutors to prepare counter-arguments.

events.title: Prosecutor notes Epstein's request for less time
events.description: An email references Epstein wanting to 'do less time' than the originally discussed 2-year deal, noting he had already gotten a break with an 18-month agreement.

keyFacts: Prosecutors express significant frustration over delays in the Epstein case, attributing them to the high-powered attorneys Epstein can afford.
The case involves more than 20 known child victims, with concerns that delays weaken the prosecution by allowing Epstein to argue victims were not minors or were motivated by money.
A plea deal had been signed several months prior, requiring Epstein to plead to uncharged crimes, and further delay could allow him to escape terms of that deal.
Prosecutors note that victims are relocating across the country and being contacted by private investigators, complicating the case.
The grand jury hearing the case is set to expire soon, and prosecutors argue it is invested and wants to indict after more than a dozen hours of testimony.
